On 9/26/11 8:39 AM, S�ren Vejrup Carlsen wrote:
>
>
> Hi there.
>
> Is there a reason why Heritrix 1 has one license (Gnu LGPL 2.1+), and
> Heritrix 3 another (Apache License 2.0)?

As I roughly recall things...

When the project first kicked off in 2003, the Apache license was still 
at version 1.1 and the GPL still at 2.0.

Of the people/groups involved in the discussions, many would have been 
comfortable with the GPL, though some had concern about this preventing 
potentially-desirable reuse by some commercial entities. Most would have 
been comfortable using the Apache license, but there were some concerns 
at the time about GPL compatibility.

The LGPL 2.1 seemed to balance all concerns, being clearly usable in all 
kinds of other projects, Apache/GPL/commercial.

Soon after, the Apache License 2.0 came out (January 2004). Over time, 
it became popular, especially in the world of Java projects/libraries. 
With GPLv3 being finalized a few years later, the FSF blessed Apache 
License 2.0 as compatible with the GPLv3.

Most of the libraries important for Heritrix are Apache-licensed, and 
other major projects of deep interest for our problem domain, such as 
Lucene/SOLR and Hadoop, are all Apache-2.0-licensed. We'd like there to 
be no friction for using code between these projects... in particular if 
we write something that makes more sense appearing in a more 
foundational library, we want them to be able to take it. And finally, 
if Heritrix or other related web-archiving projects were ever to have an 
formal organizational home outside that of the Internet Archive or 
another IIPC-member-like archiving institution, the Apache Software 
Foundation might be a candidate.

For these reasons, Heritrix wanted to move to the Apache 2.0 license at 
some point, and in early 2008 the IIPC technical committee recommended 
that the Apache 2.0 license be the default for future IIPC projects.

So, we started moving source files to Apache in the Heritrix 2.0 
development cycle. In Heritrix 3.0, the third-party libraries used 
remain under a variety of licenses which allow our use/redistribution, 
but our source is almost entirely Apache 2.0 licensed. (A few source 
files directly derived from source under other licenses retain those 
original licenses, and are marked as such.)

> Or could Heritrix 1 just as well have the same license as Heritrix 3

Are you suggesting moving the Heritrix 1.X.Y codebase to the same Apache 
License 2.0 as Heritrix 3?

My hunch is that would be a lot of effort for little benefit. Any source 
you might want to mix freely with an Apache project can probably already 
be taken from the H3 codebase. Any embedded use of H1 can probably be 
achieved through its LGPL2.1 license.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon
